title: Strange Didone from "He's Just Not That Into You" poster
content:
![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724145639im_/http:/typophile.com/files/notthatintoyou_5722.png)

I was staring at a poster for this movie while waiting for the subway, and was struck by the odd lowercase g, y and the slightly-off serifs on the cap C and S. Identifont and Whatthefont weren't much help, but I did learn that those lowercase oddities suggest a Vibert-influenced Didot. The closest I can find is [Ambroise](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724145639/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/Ambroise), but there are some definite differences (t, K, and j to name a few).

Any clues? Is this perhaps a custom mash-up of Didones?

Thanks!

—Noam
author: exfish

comments.content: I was going to say [Ambroise](http://web.archive.org/web/20140724145639/http:/www.typofonderie.com/alphabets/view/Ambroise), but the lc s is not the same. I'll keep checking ...
Looks like that s is probably an alternate that comes with Ambroise after all.

Is it? I don' see it in the PDF specimen. It's not just the s. The cap K and lc k, f in Ambroise are funky in ways that this poster is not. The lc t has a different top, the Ambroise cap G has a downward-pointing spur, and all the ball terminals in the poster feel a tad more lachrymal than your average Didone. I'm going to try getting a photo of the poster next time I take the train.

—Noam

@Cubic\_DS, good call! Didot Elder accounts for those arrowhead serifs on the cap C and S. However, in the poster the lc s has lachrymal terminals on both ends, instead of an arrowhead at the top. I'm guessing the lc s is an alternate glyph. Thanks for the help, folks!

—Noam
